text:
The worst failure of education about climate change is the idea that the cure is to go back to the direct solar resources  they had been using, that the Industrial Revolution's discovery of fossilised solar energy (coal, hydrocarbons AND the oxygen to burn them) ousted. 
That was direct sunshine, wind, and biomass. Note that for the privileged classes, biomass wasn't just horses  and elephants. It included peasants, serfs, and slaves.
Note also that there is no "wind turbine" or solar resource that can take you across the Atlantic or even the North Sea as well as a sailboat, but coal and oil have swept sailing ships away, for all military or commercial use in wealthy countries.

text:
So, I reject the notion that human activity is a primary factor in climate change. I see far more impact on our climate from natural phenomena, including solar activity and cycles in the earth's elliptical orbit around the sun. Also, the climate has been changing well before there was an significant human industrial activity in the 19th century. In fact, there were periods in history during which the climate was warmer and also cooler than the present day.

Now, that said, I do agree that humans have a negative impact on our environment. We pollute the air, land, and sea that we all depend on. This is not good and we should certainly be better stewards of the one planet we have to live on.
But, as David Saddington suggests, this is not achieved by continually repeating the same old story about the climate. Firstly, that numbs people into inaction. Secondly, proclaiming a false message of man-made climate change does even more to push away those who object to the notion.

If you want more people to take action, then try focusing on the reality of human pollution and focus on that which is relevant to them. The biggest issue I have when I hear people crying about man-made climate change is that it's often in the context of pushing more government restrictions on businesses and economic growth. And, it's often coming from people espousing more left-wing ideals. So, it's pretty easy to tune that out and completely ignore anything they're crying about.
Yet, taking care of the environment isn't a political idea. It means being a good steward of our planet. Politics should be irrelevant.

Anyway, eventually, we'll be switching over to more renewable energy sources, regardless of man-made climate change activists. As nonrenewable energy sources become more scarce, they become more expensive. And, the technology for more renewable sources will advance and help make them cheaper.
An excellent source is nuclear energy. But, the same activists who often cry about man-made climate change also seem to be against the best solution to eliminate a great deal of CO2 emissions; interesting.

Besides, if you remove too much carbon from the earth, plant life will definitely suffer.( Why do you think prehistoric plants grew to such enormous sizes with all the excess carbon dioxide in the air and MUCH warmer temperatures than today?)I'm tired of being lectured at over something that will never stop changing. If you want to improve things on this planet why not instead go after something that we CAN control that would have a far greater impact on our future? Namely pollution and overpopulation. You can pick any kind of pollution as there's certainly no end to it. Air, earth or water, take your pick. Millions of people die every year from pollution but it doesn't have the same emotional charge as climate change does and that is a real travesty. 
If you really want to improve the lives of those in third world countries, stop railing against the privileged west for their suffering. Instead, how about some education about the terrible effects of having far, far too many children that can neither be provided for nor can the region support with very FINITE amounts of both food and water. Why it even needs to be taught is beyond me. Why do mothers in impoverished regions think it is okay to have 6,7,8 or more children knowing full well that they have not enough resources to provide for 1 or 2? Surely a well-managed population/to resource allocation would have far greater effects on the local standard of living than how many cars are driven in the west.

why don't people like you care about climate change.  it is simple,  because this policy of endless growth which is destroying our climate will not reach its full maturity in your lifetime so why should you care.    that applies to everyone else that doesn't believe it.


Is climate change real or false? forget all the scientists and there graphs and figures, just deal with basic physics.

The answer lies in two simple laws of physics.

Physic law one, This is the one you practice every single day of your life,  that shows and tells you that you cannot have endless growth in a space that is not endless.   There is no need to listen to people for the answer to this question is in your everyday life  that tells you the truth., so why are you ignoring what you practice every day? because you cannot face the truth that's why.

It is physically impossible to endlessly put something into something that is not endless.   Regardless of the size of the limited space there is no exception to this law, if it is a limited space then you cannot endlessly put something into it.

If that limited space as a ecosystem that relies on balance then every species in it must be kept to a acceptable number that, that ecosystem can naturally support.

But that is not what the human species wants to do,  it wants to put an endless amount of people into this limited space and claims it will not damage or upset the natural balance of this limited space. This is because it cannot deal with  population control,  it doesn't have the emotional ability or the intelligence to discuss such a subject . It is why it is living in denial. 

 Physics law two)

It is physically impossible for a stationary object to keep up with something that is constantly moving.  No matter how far a head you put the stationary object of the thing that is moving it will always catch it up and leave it behind.
Now you can always keep moving the stationary object ahead of the thing that's moving, but to do so you will have to have endless space, if you don't have endless space then you are going to come unstuck.
 That's what happening we are coming unstuck but we are living in denial.

This should tell you,  it doesn't matter how many homes you build you will never build enough, because the problem will keep coming back as the population keeps growing.

 The quicker the population grows the quicker the problem comes back, so building homes is not the answer.

The answer is to stop the thing that is moving and keep it level with the stationary object then you have solved the problem for ever until the end of time. 

 So if you control the human population and keep it at a sensible level that each landmass can naturally support,  then you don't have problems because you are keeping the human species in balance with its environment. 

These two laws show you that climate change is real because you have a species just mindlessly endlessly multiplying into a space that is not endless, there can only be one outcome from this behaviour. And it's not going to be a good one especially for the future generations.... ie:  your children.

If anybody thinks I am wrong then I challenge you to prove me wrong,  get a limited space like a cup, then show me how you can endlessly pour water into it without it ever overflowing. Without trickery , And I will admit I am wrong.
 you can try it with any limited space and I guarantee you will fail.

text:
Why I don't care about climate change.

Because the predictions of the past have not held up to the data of today.

If we look of the past predictions; Catastrophic Weather Phenomenon would increase, Temperatures would be wildly out of control, the sea levels would have risen increasingly in rate, the ice caps would have melted completely, 90% of all crops would have failed; all of which just isn't true. Data suggests that catastrophic weather is in decline, temperatures are within normal range, the sea levels arent rising any faster or slower than they have been for hundreds of years, crops are doing better than ever, the ice caps are still there.

Don't be fooled. We are putting millions of tons of CO2 into the atmosphere. CO2 is a greenhouse gas and eventually, if we continue our use of carbon based energy, we will have a problem one day, but that day is not today, not tomorrow, not for another couple hundreds of years.

Earth, within the last 450 million years, has gone through many many changes. There are Ice Ages on record with CO2 levels 10 times higher than today. And pre-industrial CO2 levels were at an incredible 180 ppm. Today its 400. Temperature change patterns wildly around 40 degrees Celsius. Pre-industrial suggests it was 22 degrees Celsius. Today its 23.

So, I don't think climate change science has bad intentions. I think the intentions are good. But the science is bad. I think the science is what has struck so many people down with fear, and to this day fails to accept that it has incorrectly predicted the weather patterns of the future. Today, none of which that was predicted has come to pass. But we always see new studies, new thesis, new hypothesis, predictions, models, data, suggestions: the science has a bleak outlook on the future. But by the time the future comes, new studies, new thesis, new hypotheses, predictions, models, data, and suggestions dominate the debate, the past is forgotten.

My field is Sustainable Energy and this is one of the worst TED talks I sat through.


He disparages contemporary climate change rhetoric just to come up with an equally unconvincing alternative. People don't need to know about their future food shortages. They need to know HOW they can act. It is the distance between knowing and action that makes things distant, not about more detailed fearmongering about how your life is going to change.


Talk about policies instead. Talk about technologies instead. Innovate. Act. Divest. Create opportunities for the green economy to grow. Stop talking - do the harder thing.


Act.

author: Bruce Wing

text:
This talk is deeply misguided. There are two major complications:


1) Humans are very good reacting to threats they can see. Threats that are distant in time simply don't excite the same fear or flight reaction. That's why climate change is abstract - not because people think it's too scientific.


At whatever point we choose to stop carbon emissions the situation is going to get significantly worse before it will get better. There's a lag in the system response and atmospheric composition does not turn on a dime.


So if we wait until we can see things are genuinely terrible we're locked in for them getting a lot worse. What we have seen so far is the very thin end of the wedge.


2) People routinely experience temperature fluctuations of 20 degrees in a single day. This makes a 1 degree change in global mean surface temperature over a century seem very very small. They don't understand how big a deal that is.


The change in global mean surface temperature between the last glacial maximum and the pre-industrial was 3-5 degrees. The earth back then was unrecognisable despite the fact the LGM wasn't really that much colder in an absolute sense.


We're looking down the barrel of change of the same magnitude in the opposite direction at a rate 100 times faster. The suggestion that this will have negligible effects requires more than a "she'll be right"

text: Actually, forget the science and address the pound of flesh for those who give that pound of flesh in the early stages of climate policy. This is about human survival right in front of them...now! Until the human condition is addressed up front, we'll never be able to act. What am I saying? Climate change and the proposed policies will have a cost up front, and that cost will disproportionately effect the most vulnerable. People say social security/medicare are the 3rd rail of politics. Well, climate change policy is now on equal footing with the two. When legislation passed mandating the introduction of ethanol into our fuel as an early step to reduce carbon emissions, it created chaos in the commodities market. The price spikes had a major impact on my industry. I watched over the course of two years, clients lose their business', homes & livelihoods. I wasn't personally effected, but obviously, the impact was stunning. Today, it is agreed that the legislation by all was a wash, as the reduction in emissions from vehicles was lost in the manufacturing process. Those whom proposed the legislation went on about their lives as normal, feeling no impact. When you add the impact of trade policy like NAFTA, China's entry into the WTO, and the massive loss in jobs to working Americans, people become bitter. They soon don't trust Govt & the elites. Add, "I'm going to shut down the coal industry"...how did that make the millions of people in that industry feel, or others in industries that heard that? This is how you get a Donald Trump elected. I am a Liberal, but the failure of our side to understand this dynamic only exacerbates a lag in climate policy. We must address everyday working people first by enact parallel policy to climate change policy. Until then, we can argue all we want, but a massive part of the population(Both R's & D's) is not going to support anything if they pay the largest pound of flesh up front, while others feel very little impact.

Moreover, we should plant more trees. Even if you don't believe in climate change, surely you enjoy the sight of trees, and the birds that live in them?


I am sceptical of the science behind climate change, but we should still move towards a nicer world anyway, just for the pleasure of being alive.

Dire times are now ahead but wouldn't it be wonderful if....IF,  humanity could finally learn the lesson that when you put peoples welfare first and support everyone leaving no group out or brushed aside that we can have a world where life is worth living for everyone. It is a hope that could be a reality despite the fact we are facing the most traumatic and frightening page in human history that we will ever face!!

text:
This cycle has repeated time and time again throughout history. Carbon 
levels rise, heat level rises correspondingly creating an ideal 
environment, that being hot with high carbon levels and high levels of 
storms bringing water into the central continents to feed to 
rainforests. The over abundance of oxygen producing plants then begin to
 deplete the atmosphere of CO2 and the earth begins too cool. It reaches
 a point where plants are locked into the equatorial zones, the ice 
sheets push down, and lower water levels cause droughts that exacerbate 
the loss of plant life. Eventually, CO2 levels begin the rise, and the 
cycle begins again. Climate change isn't bad, it's the natural order of 
the world.
author: Lines Angus

text: 9th Dimension when ice bergs melt in the middle of the sea, water levels do not change as the displacement of water is the same (when the water is frozen in the ice berg, or liquid in the sea.) Your ice berg (ice cub) takes up the same amount of volume if its a solid or a liquid in the ocean (your glass of water.) However, when ice on land melts (like glaciers, or ice and snow in Antartica) it enters our oceans, as more mass is being displaced into them. That water that previously is frozen on land, is added to the oceans. Its not a scam.

text: Ehhhhhh...wrong. Water has been a source of conflict since the dawn of time. I've not read any science that convinced me mankind's doom will be global warming/climate change. I work with scientists who have varied opinions of cause and effect on a wide range of problematic man-made issues from climate change to degradation of nitrogen levels in native grasslands due to grazing or raised bacteria levels in our waterways. So...spin your spinny spinster message how you want. Yes there are plenty of 'now' problems, but people are on these problems and working toward solutions...and oh by the way...look at the list of top global polluters...the U.S. is by far the one nation cutting emissions and taking economic, entrepreneurial and educational steps to curb pollutants.

text:
I used to believe these claims about climate change until I found out that they never asked climate scientists about the usefulness of carbon taxes and tariffs. Climate scientists agree that CO2 has an impact. They don't all agree that it should be a political issue or that the impact is justification for carbon taxes and tariffs. They aren't skeptical of science they are skeptical of politicians. Here are few good reasons why:

1. Humanities primate ancestors were alive when there was 4000ppm CO2. That's a hard pill to swallow when we're squawking over 400, and good evidence against runaway green house effects. 
2. In the ice core data temperature always changes before CO2 and the lag is thousands of years. So there's no evidence on a geological timescale that temperature would follow CO2.
3. CO2 can absorb all radiation in its spectrum with its current level, increasing it makes it absorb these wavelengths a few meters further up. 
4. Water is the main green house gas by far. It absorbs a wider spectrum of light and because it moves through a huge range of altitudes it insulates Earth much better than CO2 which stays near the ground after it cools from being emitted.
5. Plants are made of carbon and get it from the air. More CO2 could potentially make plant life grow better for that reason alone.  

Teachers in environmental science classes and politicians have all been taught an oversimplified political propaganda. Our best and brightest have been deluded because CO2 does have a hard to understand, but undeniable impact. They just never realized that the impact is minuscule because no one bothered to teach them that. There are other real environmental issues and they usually involve over fishing, over grazing, deforestation, or extinction from habitat loss and toxic pollutants not green house gasses.

text:
First, let me advise you a couple of channels, potholer54 and professor stick, that debunk conclusion like yours. 
Second let me address some of the points you made. 
1) the fact that carbon rates were higher doesn't mean they won't have devastating consequences today. Thousands of years ago wasn't after all the pinacle of standard of living.
2) yes carbon lags temperature by a few hundred years in the ice record. This is because a small amount of warming, triggered by melankovich cycles releases CO2 from the ocean and the ice sheets, which in term warms the climate even more and that positive feedback leads the climate into a warmer equilibrium.
3) yes water vapor is a stronger greenhouse, which is why we're lucky there isn't much of it; the partial pressure of WV at room temperature is about 20mbar. This however does increase with temperature, which is what is happening, and I hope you can see where this is going.
Climate change is humanities greatest obstacle right now, as while the human race might survive, many people's lives are at stake, and we must do everything in our power to stop it or mitigate its effects

text:
Key Questions to Ask about the Truth of Climate Change
Here are a set of questions, any of which would lead to the conclusion that we don’t need to spend a dime on global warming.  I will assume that for each question that we answer in support of climate change.  Just realize that at any point of the questions that a no or not sure invalidates any logic that we should spend billions or trillions of dollars.


 1)  Is the world actually warming?  

The earth has actually been in a cooling phase or at least a pause for the last 18 years.  Thus the change to climate change to further obfuscate the issue.  But let us say the earth is warming, then the question is:


2)  Is the climate change significant enough to pose a threat to the planet?  

The earth has been going thru changes in climate constantly, from seasons, to decades to eons.  Normal fluctuations have been occurring forever without humans being the cause.  But again let’s assume there is some sort of threat that we should pay attention to.


3)  Is the climate change being caused by humans?  

CO2, the culprit most cited by global warming alarmist, is only  400 parts per million in the atmosphere.  The vast majority of CO2 comes from the oceans, decaying biomass and volcanoes.  Only one-tenth of CO2 comes from humans or 40 parts in one million.  CO2 has ranged from 7,000 parts per million to as low as 180 parts per million - and life survived.  In fact in times of higher CO2 concentrations, agriculture flourished, famine was reduced and human advancement increased.  But let’s for argument sake global warming is real, it poses a threat and it is man made.



4)  Is there something that we can practically do to change the threat of global warming?

Short of shutting down all fossil fuel consumption, what is it we can do?  Will better MPG or electric cars (which use energy from electric plants that predominately burn fossil fuels) stop climate change?  Will going to all solar and wind help?  BTW only about 3% of US energy comes from the highly subsidized and a yet unprofitable businesses.  We do not technology or resources to provide the energy needed to run the US economy; and won’t have it for decades.  If we shut everything down will it make a difference?  What data, analysis, or studies show that a 100% effort by humans would change the natural temperature cycles the earth has experienced?  But let’s assume we can, next question:



5)  If there are practical things we can do, are they affordable?   Who is going to pay for all this climate change remediation?  

Do we even have a plan of what actions we would take, what the timeline would be, or most importantly how much it would cost?  Will the poorest 120 countries contribute any money?  Probably not.  will India or China (who both out pollute the US) agree to divert huge national resources away from their growing economies to solve a problem that many believe doesn’t even exist.  can the US, which already $20T in debt have the resources?  All the billionaires in the US only have about 2.2T and all the millionaires only about $19T.  Where does the money come from?  Especially if we want to continue to increase entitlements?  But let’s assume we can afford it.  

6)  Do we as citizens of the world have the political will to allow our leaders to effect massive changes that directly affect our pocketbooks, our lifestyles and consumption patterns?   

Would we be willing to go back to the lifestyle of the pre-industrial world?  No electricity, no cars, no iPhones, no lights, no A/C?  Okay, maybe no that drastic - how about limiting car usage, rationing electricity,  moving us all into smaller “sustainable” homes?  

If we restrict fossil fuels won’t people start cutting down trees to heat their homes and doing other unhealthy environmental things?  What do we do when nations ignore the rules?  Do we succumb to a one-world government that has the power and control to force us?

Is it global warming real? Is it a threat? Are humans a significant cause? Is there something we can do about it?  Can we afford to fix it? 

Finally, are we all willing to sacrifice, money, freedoms, and lifestyle to make it happen? It is a lot of ifs, and I for one am not willing to give government further control of my life on a bunch of flimsy ifs.  

I am not a climate denier, I am a government skeptic!! Do we need to be prudent proactive stewards of the earth?  Of course!  Do we need to be told to change our lives based on politicized science - not on my watch

text:
What's the message?
~ Educate individuals on local impacts, from climate change, to motivate regional and global mitigation.

IMO -- Given the fact that weather is local and climate** is regional and global, and the effects of climate change are mixed at the local and regional level, and the effects are gradual from a human attention span, what are the risks and benefits to his strategy?

~ Local losers will be    more motivated    to mitigate:
   > Increased temps in hot regions and decreased temps in cold regions.
   > Less rain in dry regions and more rain in wet regions.
   > More incidents of catastrophic weather in regions typically not having catastrophic weather.
   > Due to their financial weakness, emerging or developing regions are less able to mitigate the climate change impacts at the local and  regional levels.
   > Impact to exporting countries  -- Reduced income from exports, increased unemployment, less money for consumption, reduced GDP,  reduced taxes for infrastructure.

~ Local winners will be    less motivated    to mitigate:
   > Increased temps in cold regions and decreased temps in hot regions.
   > Less rain in wet regions and more rain in dry regions.
   > Less incidents of catastrophic weather in regions typically having catastrophic weather.
   > Due to their financial strength, modern regions can better mitigate the climate change impacts at the local and maybe regional levels.
   > Mixed impact to importing countries - Less competition for domestic competitors, increased employment in that industry,  increased costs to consumers and less spending on other goods and services, switch to less costly alternatives if possible. 
   > Modern economies are based on technologies that exploit fossil fuels that produce gases that negatively impact the climate.
   > Developing economics desire to improve their economies and quality of life by exploiting fossil fuels just like developed countries have demonstrated.

If he's getting the message across, I hope for the best he can continue doing it.


** Climate is at the regional/planet level that subsumes all weather measurements over a given period of time in that region/planet. It doesn't consider political boundaries. To estimate Climate we must include, due to thermodynamics, metrics from the ocean at different depths, in the air at different altitudes, on the ground, and weather at different locations and times.
    Weather is a local term such as the weather in your house, on the north side, or on the south side of your house at a certain time of day. The weather on the north and south
    sides can be quite different throughout the day. There is weather in your neighborhood or city which can be different than at your house due to the placement of trees, concrete, grass, and other structures that affect air flow or reflect the sun.

But telling that to the public, all the details and intricacies, does nothing. What needs to be told, is how it effects us and how to stop it. We shouldn't care about climate change itself so much. Telling them the inner workings could make a fun and interesting seminar, but that's not what's important now is it. Instead of letting them try to derive what was important about it, we should be saying the important stuff from the start. That way it's possible to understand more.

text: So much rubbish here. First off educate children that climate change is permanent and has been since the birth of the planet. Second educate children that its the height of arrogance that humans should try to alter the climate to suit our convenience rather than adapt to the changes. Third a warming planet will increase crop yields not reduce them. The forth coming glacial period will not be pleasant for humans. Fourth a rising temperature will result in rising water vapour content in the atmosphere thus reducing drought. Fifth advancing technology is enhancing crop yields and lowering prices on a permanent basis. I could go on. Mr Saddington have you any idea how much co2 there is in the atmosphere? 400 parts per million right? just 2% of which is attributed to humans. At that rate you would have a band of co2 caused by humans just 240mm thick in any column of air between the ground and space at 100km high. (99% of air is in the first 30km). This is not going to affect the temperature of the planet. The Sun heats the planet not a band of co2 just 240mm thick. What you should really do is divest yourself of all the benefits given to you by fossil fuels such as healthcare, sanitation, gas central heating, your car, your phone, your house, travel, your TV, anything plastic etc etc etc and set a fine example living off the land in a grass hut and cultivating some medicinal herbs for when you get poorly. I would accept a compromise perhaps if you were to go and live in a third world country where there is no power available or schools or hospitals for five years then come back and educate everyone  as to your first hand insights concerning the noticeable benefits of fossil fuels. Also maybe explain which of the countries you've lived in is most likely to solve the problems you envisage.

text:
The flash flood you experienced was likely due to watercourses blocked with weeds. This arose  through EU policies banning dredging. (Well, the actual problem was regulations which made it next to impossible to dispose of the dredged silt, but the effect was the same.) That, coupled with hill farming subsidies which have led to stripping of vegetation from uplands, leading to fast runoff of water. 

Now, I ask you, who predicted catastrophic floods, when, and what relation do those organisations have to the regulatory bodies whose stupidity in preventing watercourse maintenance in a land which always has had heavy rainfall, led to these catastrophic floods?

Of course, you might wonder if it was actually stupidity. It did not surprise me at all when the floods were claimed to be proof of climate change. 

My sympathy goes to all those who have lost their homes through this corruption. I myself narrowly avoided being one of their number. I sold rather than continue to take the risk on an uninsurable house in a street where two neighbours had been flooded out. On speaking to one of the local watercourse maintainers he made the situation clear to me. The house I sold at a reduced price has not since been flooded, and that is because the watercourses were cleared.  

Round about this time I became interested in climate change, and with my scientific background I was not prepared to take propaganda or hyperbole at face value. The truth is there, but only for those who are prepared to seek it for themselves. Some aspects of that truth are, indeed, downright worrying.

The threat of Climate Change is more difficult to show that the far simpler fact that the planet must radiate back out, all of the energy that solar radiation brings in, and that the largest absorber is the oceans, >75% of the surface. It takes a huge amount of energy to raise the temperature of a cubic metre of water by one degree, even if it's only a Fahrenheit degree.
If only 99.98% of the energy from the sun  is radiated back into space, that leaves a very considerable amount of energy being collected. See the work of James Hansen for actual evaluations.

text: Some Easy maths. Co2 levels 408ppm. Methane levels 2000ppb or 2ppm. Hang on 2ppm, that's has got to be harmless right?....... Wrong! ....Methane is 120 times more potent than Co2. So convert Methane into Co2 = 220ppm. Which it does naturally over a given time period. So 408 + 220 = Co2 levels of 628. Now take NASA and other scientists calculations that Doubling of Co2 from 280ppm to 560ppm will = SRF (Solar Radiative Forcing) of 3.6w/m2. This = warming of 4'c as calculated by most scientific bodies around the world. Lag time circa 20 - 40 years. Now add in our second most powerful green house gas Water Vapour. For every 1'c of warming water vapour increases by 7%. 4'c = 28% increase in Water Vapour + compounding of 2%. Water vapour increases SRF by another 2w/m2 or 2'c. So that's 6'c so far. Scientists studying Methane Clathrate/Hydrate dissolution know that the Earth must warm by 6'c for deep sea Methane Clathrate/Hydrate to become unstable and dissolve. Without these trace gases Earth would be at -15'c. A snowball earth, which it did achieve twice 100s of million years ago.

text: We are in a "Tragedy of the Commons" type situation with climate change.  Right now, it makes more economic sense at the micro-economic level to minimize your energy costs, and socialize all the losses (climate change and pollution).  Investments in "green energy" are competing against investments with much quicker payback periods (and possibly higher returns), so they are at a financial disadvantage.  This has to change if any progress is to be made.  That's where governments will have to step in and tax fossil fuels (carbon tax) and/or subsidize "green" technologies.  You can't fix this problem with altruistic environmentalism.

How can you prove the world is getting warmer? There are no certifications on any of the charts. I can easily fake them all and show a mini ice age on the way. The problem is that there are more scientists around than money to support them.  Now they are all willing to fake charts and lie their butts off to get a grant. They are quickly becoming the world's most disrespected profession!  

The arctic is melting due to black soot settling on the ice increasing the absorption of heat from the sun. The black soot is evidenced in almost all videos of the ice sheets and the glaziers. Look at the melting ice! It is gray and even black in some ares. This is exactly what happened on Greenland. It has happen before when volcanic ash settled on the ice. 

The problem is massive amounts of volcanic ash from eruptions on Iceland and other parts of the world.  Forest fires plus the burning of dirty coal by China, India, and other poor nations also play a major role. When you darken the ice with black soot and ash, the sun can easily melt it. Lying scientists are wasting money and valuable time. 

We do need to clean the air of black soot and ash, not harmless CO2.

text: Keeping It Reel I'm going to give you the benefit of the doubt and guess that you're just apathetic. Climate change is real, there is no argument there. Temperature is getting hotter in summer and more brutally cold in winter, these massive hurricanes and tropical storms of unparalleled size, the ice caps melting. On that note, humans are not doing it. A loong time ago about 500 million years ago the CO2 ppm was about 7000ppm. Now it's just over 400ppm and people are losing their minds. Higher CO2 promotes plant growth which has happened over the past 35 years worldwide where Forrest and jungles are growing faster than ever in recorded history. The earth has been through 5 ice ages. That is a trend. Just like any other natural phenomena it will happen again. People fighting that is ok though right? Even though the whole argument with CO2 is we added it now it's ok to interfere with the earth healing itself. The earth will do what it has to so it keeps going. People are here for the ride. It doesn't hurt having renewable resources and energy because why use stuff that never comes back? Just dont think a world of green energy is going to save us.
author: Matthew Giles

text: Matthew Giles faster growing plants isn't necessarily better lol. First of all that only applies to C3 plants. C4 and CAM photosynthesis plants are actually at a disadvantage. This includes corn which is not only a staple food crop but a staple for biofuel production (ethanol). Second of all, C3 plants growing faster and producing more sugar is at the expense of nutrient density. This means that C3 crops humans eat are getting more sugary and less nutritious with increased atmospheric concentrations of CO2. That's definitely a downside. Plants are also affected by climate change because they cannot expand their range as rapidly as animals can, since they're immobile. As temperatures rise, the ideal range of plants will be further from the equator. Plants that don't adapt quickly enough will become extinct. Another way is through desertification. Deserts are EXPANDING, forests aren't getting bigger. Deserts = less green cover and very little biodiversity. Few plants are adapted to arid conditions but again, at this rate of change most plants won't be able to adapt genetically before becoming extinct.

author: Matthew Giles

text: Matthew Giles it's true that the earth usually does a pretty good job of handling disturbances and returning to some sort of equilibrium but the Earth also isn't invincible. There really isn't a lack of factual evidence (which is about as certain as you can be about anything) that climate change as it's occurring NOW is human driven. It's not saying that humans are the only cause, but they are the main contributor. Obviously there are lots of other natural factors that contribute to climate fluctuations but the changes occurring now are unprecented. Scientific analysis is not the same as an "educated guess". Hypotheses and theories about climate change may not be 100% correct but they are backed by ample empirical findings. Nothing is for certain if you want to get down into it, and climate science is a field of active research. Skepticism is important but denying human-driven climate change is ignoring mountains of data and empirical evidence, and is similar to denying evolution or the theory of gravity. Nearly everyone who denies human-driven climate change has not even taken the time to learn the science of it, including mechanisms down to the molecular level. It's also not that hard to put two and two together. Manmade industry releases gases like CO2, NOx, CH4 etc (more so than things like volcanoes) Atmospheric concentrations of these gases increase. These gas molecules capture heat energy due to their rotational chemistry and re-emit it back to the earth. Earth warms. It's not rocket science... but it is science.

text: What is there to "DO"?! Volcanoes put more pollutants into the atmosphere than all the autos  and factories put together. Are we supposed to put corks in them? C'mon! There has been climate change throughout the life of the planet. At one time the globe was frozen solid, save the deepest parts of the oceans. Plate tectonics and volcanoes were all that saved the globe. During the age of the dinosaurs, there were no polar ice caps. That changed. We are just coming out of an ice age. That is changing but again. There are a lot of people making a lot of money preaching about this subject. Besides, how do we know this warmer environment will not be better. He speaks of wheat yields, etc. but does not mention the fact that the soils have been weekend due to mono-culture agriculture over the years. Perhaps, when this current change comes to fruition, wheat can be grown at more northerly sites, where the soils have not been depleted. These doomsayers will not be alive to see the subsequent results. No one will hold their feet to the fire for their predictions. So it is safe for them to espouse their views without repercussions when they are proven wrong.

It's the fact that it's changing so RAPIDLY that is not good. You want an example? I'll give you one. Cape Town, the capitol of South Africa, will shut off its taps in 2018, due to DROUGHT CAUSED BY CLIMATE CHANGE. That DEFINITELY proves that people can "espouse their views without repercussions when they are proven wrong" in your words. They're wrong when I'm a mouse. Climate change is occurring FAST, and you can see the affects of it. Also, it's not that easy to just change where you grow crops. How will you convince the people at the "more northerly sites" to move? You've got to convince people to move first, and humans are stubborn. Think it through. Climate change is real, and you are short-sighted, just like Christian Gerber is. Think about more than just yourself. Think about the people in coastal areas that will have to flee rising seas. We know this, because people have actually flown instruments up there to measure the atmosphere. We know what molecules are there and in what proportion. text:
WTF are you talking about. For most of Earth history C02 levels have been much higher than we see today; much higher. In fact we are in a LOW period of C02 concentration. Explain the higher concentrations of C02 for extreme periods of time BEFORE the existence of humans.

The rate of increase in C02 and temp is too fast? well that same increase happened between 1910 and 1940 - long before the massive industrial revolution we have today. Please explain. 

C02 levels follow temperature rise - not the other way round. What is causing the temps to rise is the main question. Too many variables to consider one overall source. Volcanic activity, Sun activity, cloud saturation etc., all play a part; and NONE of those are within the control of humans. 

What dictates a lot of our global temperatures? Clouds. The coverage amount and their formation dictates most of our climate. Less cloud cover and you have hotter temps and vice-versa. Show me a computer model that can predict the formation and movement of clouds accurately more than 3 days out, let alone 50-100 years.

More C02 means a greener planet. A greener planet means more vegetation. More vegetation means less starvation. Climate hoaxers would rather "save the planet" than "save the people".

author: NZJacobNZ

text:
Okay, fair, the density of people at the equator is greater at the equator than at the poles but the largest density of people certainly isn't at the equator, it's roughly 40 degrees north of the equator somewhere roughly around China/India. This would imply we're at about the ideal temperature for human existence.

But regardless of what humans prefer, we need to consider the total impact of climate on human existence. If you make the climate harsher - more deserts, extreme weather events etc then it's going to be harder for humankind to exist and there will be more starvation in the world due to food shortages. We need world hunger to decrease, not increase, as i'm sure we both agree. 

Yes, CO2 is not itself directly harmful to humans, but burning fossil fuels which produce it certainly is. Places like China and the US have a large number of citizens die from emissions related deaths each year and that is why many cities around the world are soon adopting an emissions free zone in the city center.

I agree, i don't think oil reserves are going to run out anytime soon. But I do believe with the rapid falling price of both solar (http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/guest-blog/smaller-cheaper-faster-does-moores-law-apply-to-solar-cells/) and wind energy technologies (http://sites.psu.edu/math033fa15/2015/10/16/assignment-2-wind-turbines-final-paper/), coupled with the even more rapid falling price of energy storage technologies (http://cleantechnica.com/2015/03/04/energy-storage-could-reach-cost-holy-grail-within-5-years/) we certainly see oil peak in our lifetimes.

Saying that, you're right that things like solar and wind aren't 24-7 reliable, which is a problem. That's why they must be coupled with clean load following power plants like generation 4 nuclear fission (or fusion if we get there) plus energy storage like batteries.

What is this free energy you keep speaking of? Nothing comes for free, there is always the initial capital cost of setting up the plant plus that of maintenance.

Plus, please stop insulting me. That is hardly the way to educate someone and have them come around to your point of view. Peace brother. I'm willing to listen.

text:
The name didn't keep changing, that's probably just a meme you read and repeat without any critical analysis or attempt at verification in credible sources. "Greenhouse effect" is what causes "global warming", which in turn causes "climatic changes"..

The same with lumping "another ice age" with it. Another is predicted only for much later (like 1500 years), as a natural cycle according to the Earth's orbit pattern, but it's speculated that global warming itself could disrupt flows of ocean currents ("the Gulf Stream") that currently make Great Britain not as cold as predicted for its latitude, about as cold as Canada or Siberia, and that then be some sort of ice-age type of thing, I'm not sure the technical term, or how robust and precise such predictions are supposed to be according to the scientists themselves.

Another "ice-age" meme is related with aerosol (particulate) pollution, wich increases the Earth's reflectivity (reducing global warming), and cools the planet. For some time some scientists speculated this form of pollution would compensate warming by greenhouse gases, but it turned out to be wrong, perhaps partly because of legislation restricting this kind of pollution, which is associated with smog and detrimental health effects.

Take a look at any time lapse film, say over a five year period, of sand dunes. Then try to tell me that an ice core sample can  accurately catalog yearly snowfall I grew up in the far north and one of the first things I learned is that a single worm day followed by a sudden cold snap will create a glaze of ice that will cause all the rest of the snow for that winter to blow into huge drifts against any barrier that disrupts the smooth flow of the wind. FYI we have no knowledge of  prevailing wind direction or strength even a hundred years ago never mind hundreds of thousands of years ago. 

Not to kick you when you are down, but the second thing that I learned is that you get very little snow fall at temperatures below -10F because to reach those  temperatures requires relatively dry air. So the correlation between snowfall and temperature is a myth only true ware the normal coldest temperatures seldom reach below -5F and therefor you have no permanent snowpack to take icecors from.

text:
@***** 
Well I agree that we either are unable or it is impractical or immoral to control our population growth. Like huge numbers of people, I also have many objections to all methods of birth control. I believe that humans really should not restrain the natural growth of our numbers.

Did you mean "safest" way, or most sure way? But both can easily be disputed. Most people are especially against such draconian population control measures, and even if population growth might be a concern, I think most people still do not see much anything that can be done to slow population growth. Only decades ago, even "overpopulation" talk seemed to admit that population growth could not really much controlled at all. It was acknowledged that so many people have objections to birth control. And there has been a lot of thought that people really do want families of a size that keeps population growing.

We have to make room for more people, as our numbers rise by another billion people per decade. Why does anybody think we have any choice, as to whether to make room for more people? People do not want to be told how many children they can have. When we have people in my own congregation, who have as many as 5 and 6 children, it perhaps tells me something about where I hope that the world population situation is going. I welcome a human-denser world, as it is the right pro-life thing to do. There is just getting to be so many of us humans, and human life is a big deal, every human life is of immense value, and every human life is sacred. Many people believe that sex should remain ever open to the prospect of pregnancy, meaning do not take any preventative measures to block pregnancy, lest sex is made to be profaned, selfish, and carnal. I think that contraceptives are so disgusting in so many ways.

As a pro-lifer, of course I agree with reducing premature and unnecessary deaths, while leaving birthrate naturally high as it should be. There is no moral imperative to somehow keep the world from naturally "blowing up" with people. Let human population grow however high that they can get to. God knows what he is doing, and what is good for us.

No reverse option? Why would we want to go backwards? More and more people would be glad to live. Let baby booms take hold all over the world, and let human population soar as it may. God commanded that we humans multiply, so that makes population size, God's determination, and not that of small-thinking evil and rebellious elitist power-mad men.

BTW, people in Nigeria say that children are gifts from God, they see their population growth as good for their economy, and people there seem to want as many children as they can produce. What really is wrong with such pro-life thinking? You do know that in many countries of the world, not so much like the wicked or corrupted West, abortion is still frowned upon and banned. Human life is a big deal. Our ancestors believed that growth is good, and I believe that human populations everywhere should still grow naturally, meaning without use of any means of birth control. Encourage people to pair up, get married younger if they are ready, and let the babies freely pump out.

Take action on overpopulation? That sounds needlessly brutal and cruel, and quite unnecessary. What could be more natural for people, than to let their babies naturally push out?
